contentrichtext.text: {{coord|54.352|-5.731|display=title|region:GB_scale:100000}} {{NI_district | district_name = Down District | alt_name = | district_logo = [[Image:Strangford (18), August 2009.JPG|200px]] <br /> <small>Sign bearing Down District Council logo</small> | district_map = [[File:Down in Northern Ireland.svg|250px]] | area_rank = 7th | district_area = 647 | district_HQ = [[Downpatrick]] | district_iso = GB-DOW | district_ons = 95R | <!-- Fetch dynamic statistics from Template:PopLookupNI --> protestant_pc = 32.1% | catholic_pc = 62.5% | district_control = '''No overall control''' <br />[[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]]: 9 <br /> [[Sinn Féin]]: 5 <br /> [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]]: 3 <br /> [[Ulster Unionist Party|UUP]]: 3 <br /> [[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland|Alliance Party]]: 1 <br />[[Green Party in Northern Ireland|Green Party]]: 1 <br />[[Independent (politician)|Independent]]: 1 | district_MLAs = '''[[South Down (Assembly constituency)|South Down]]''' & '''[[Strangford (Assembly constituency)|Strangford]]''' <br /> [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]]: 4 <br /> [[Ulster Unionist Party|UUP]]: 3 <br /> [[Sinn Féin]]: 2 <br />[[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]]: 2 <br /> [[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland|Alliance Party]]: 1 | district_MPs = [[Margaret Ritchie (politician)|Margaret Ritchie]] (SDLP) <br>[[Jim Shannon]] (DUP) | meeting_place = | web_address = http://www.downdc.gov.uk | }} '''Down District Council''' is a Local Council in [[County Down]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. The Council is headquartered in [[Downpatrick]]. Other towns in the Council area are [[Ardglass]], [[Ballynahinch, County Down|Ballynahinch]], [[Castlewellan]], [[Clough]], [[Crossgar]], [[Dundrum, County Down|Dundrum]], [[Killough]], [[Killyleagh]], [[Newcastle, County Down|Newcastle]], [[Saintfield]], [[Seaforde]] and [[Strangford]]. It covers a population of nearly 64,000. The Down District Council area consists of 4 electoral areas: Ballynahinch, Downpatrick, Newcastle and Rowallane. At the last election in 2011, 23 Councillors were elected from the following political parties: 9 [[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]], 5 [[Sinn Féin]], 3 [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]], 3 [[Ulster Unionist Party|UUP]], 1 [[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland|Alliance Party]], 1 [[Green Party in Northern Ireland|Green Party]], 1 [[Independent (politician)|Independent]]. The Council Chairman for the 2011/2012 council term is Councillor Dermot Curran (SDLP) and the Vice Chair is Councillor Liam Johnston (Sinn Féin). In elections for the [[Westminster Parliament]] it is split between the [[Strangford (UK Parliament constituency)|Strangford constituency]] and the [[South Down (UK Parliament constituency)|South Down constituency]]. ==Work of the Council== The Council has periodically had to provide funding to ensure that the [[Saint Patrick Visitor Centre]] in [[Downpatrick]] remains in operation. It has also funded a major promenade infrastructure regeneration in [[Newcastle, County Down|Newcastle]]. The new promenade has won a number of National awards including a [[Civic Trust Awards|Civic Trust]] Award for Excellence in the Public Realm. ==Review of Public Administration== Under the Review of Public Administration (RPA) the Council was due to merge with [[Newry and Mourne District Council]] in 2011 to form a single council for the enlarged area totalling 1539 km² and a population of 150,886.<ref>{{cite web | title=Minister Foster announces decisions on Local Government Reform | work=DoE | url=http://www.doeni.gov.uk/index/local_government/minister_foster_announces_decisions_on_local_government_reform.htm | accessdate=2008-05-31}}</ref> The first election to the new council was due to take place in May 2009, but on 25 April 2008, [[Shaun Woodward]], [[Secretary of State for Northern Ireland]] announced that the scheduled 2009 district council elections were to be postponed until the introduction of the eleven new councils in 2011.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7367253.stm ''Northern Ireland elections are postponed'', BBC News, April 25, 2008, accessed April 27, 2008]</ref> The planned change was abandoned in 2010 and the most recent election took place in May 2011 under the existing boundaries. ==See also== *[[Local Councils in Northern Ireland]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Down District Council}} ==External links== * [http://www.downdc.gov.uk/welcome.asp Down District Council] website *[http://www.armaghanddown.com/ Armagh and Down Tourism] *[http://www.downcountymuseum.com/ Down County Museum] *[http://www.downartscentre.com Down Arts Centre] {{Northern Ireland Local Government}} [[Category:Politics of County Down]] [[Category:Downpatrick]] [[Category:Local authorities of Northern Ireland]]
